monogr.title: Queen Charlotte and Johnny Bull Got Their Dose of Perry

projectDesc.p: The Historic Images, New Technologies (HINT) project aims to enhance description and discovery of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania's graphics materials and promote the linking and sharing of content among institutions and scholars. The project will result in an update to HSP's digital image viewer and an online digital history exhibit that will demonstrate the new viewer's capabilities and provide interpretive and contextual materials to encourage users to interact with historical images in new ways. This project was funded by a grant from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission's (NHPRC) Innovation in Archives and Documentary Editing program

div.p: Queen Charlotte of England and John Bull (a symbolic character representing Great Britain) react to news of American naval commander Matthew Perry's victories during the War of 1812. At left, Queen Charlotte, drunk and hiccuping, offers a bottle of perry (an alcoholic drink made of fermented pears) to John Bull, at right, who is sitting on a commode (toilet) and suffering from a stomachache. The bottle is spraying out streams of liquid, each labeled with the name of an American warship that fought in the Battle of Lake Erie, where Perry won a decisive victory. At John Bull's feet lie scattered pages of newspapers and letters announcing America's victories, including the destruction of the British warship Charlotte. John Bull complains that, in addition to his indigestion, he has not yet recovered from the bloody nose he received at the "Boxing Match" (the title of another political cartoon by William Charles).

div.head: Queen Charlotte and Johnny Bull Got their dose of Perry

div.p: Phla Pubd and sold at 12 Chesnut Chestnut St
Johnny wont you take some more Perry! I did not think it was composed of such strong Ingredients _ Hic up _ I wish I had not tried its strength _ I _ I _ I am quite over power'd by it--

Oh! Perry!!! Curse that Perry! _ It has Griped me enough already _ Such a revolution in my guts _ One disaster after another _ I have not half recovered of the Bloody nose I got at the Boxing Match!_See "The Boxing Match" (cartoon)

head.note: Liquid shoots out of a bottle labeled "Perry"; each spray is labeled with the name of American warships that fought in the Battle of Lake Erie.

div.p: Wm Charles del et Sculp."Del et Sculp" means "drawn and engraved."
LONDON. EX GAZETTE By Authority My Lords and Gentlemen_ I am sorry to you Loss
illegible of the CharlotteThe Charlotte was a British warship defeated during the Battle of Lake Erie.
